DataElement.preferredName: Follow-up Recurrence Death Malignant Neoplasm Status Number Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Records the presence or absence of clinical evidence of the patient's malignant or non-malignant tumor as of the Date of Last Contact [1750].

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Follow-up Recurrence Death Malignant Neoplasm Status
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The presence or absence of clinical evidence of the patient's malignant or non-malignant tumor.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The process by which information about the health status of an individual is obtained after a study has officially closed.:To occur again.:The absence of life or state of being dead.

Concepts.definition: The process by which information about the health status of an individual is obtained after a study has officially closed; an activity that continues something that has already begun or that repeats something that has already been done.

Property.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.:A condition or state at a particular time.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
A condition or state at a particular time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A term for diseases in which abnormal cells divide without control. Cancer cells can invade nearby tissues and can spread through the bloodstream and lymphatic system to other parts of the body._A condition or state at a particular time._Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification._A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Unknown, indeternimate whether this tumor is present, not stated in patient record.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Unknown, indeternimate whether this tumor is present, not stated in patient record.
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Unknown, indeternimate whether this tumor is present, not stated in patient record.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:A condition or state at a particular time.:Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
A condition or state at a particular time.
A numeral or string of numerals expressing value, quantity, or identification.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

ValueDomain.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries
